key_points: Texas officially updated its winter storm death toll to 210, an increase of 59 deaths.
Most victims died of hypothermia, with vehicle crashes, carbon monoxide poisoning, and complications from chronic medical conditions also leading causes.
The historic freeze in February left millions without power for days.
Harris County reported the highest number of deaths at 43, followed by Travis and Dallas Counties with 28 and 20 deaths respectively.
The Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) acknowledges the death toll may be an underestimation.
Buzzfeed analysis suggests the actual number of deaths could exceed 700.
DSHS plans to continue updating the death tally as more information becomes available.
The winter storm highlighted significant deficiencies in Texas' electric system.
Legislation was passed to increase the reliability of the state's power grid, though some argue it was insufficient.
Governor Greg Abbott faces criticism for not including grid reforms in the special legislative session agenda.
